channel.title: tastytrade: Options Jive
channel.description: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Learn to talk the talk - sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss trading topics of the day.
channel.itunes:author: tastytrade
channel.itunes:summary: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.googleplay:author: tastytrade, Inc.

item.title: How Does IV Move With Markets?
item.description: When looking at correlation between equity markets and IV, we see a strong negative correlation which means that they move opposite. In fact, SPY and its IV are one of the most negatively correlated products on the market. On a percentage basis, VIX (SPY IV) is about 5 times more volatile than the percentage move in SPY.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: When looking at correlation between equity markets and IV, we see a strong negative correlation which means that they move opposite. In fact, SPY and its IV are one of the most negatively correlated products on the market. On a percentage basis, V...

In fact, SPY and its IV are one of the most negatively correlated products on the market. On a percentage basis, VIX (SPY IV) is about 5 times more volatile than the percentage move in SPY.

item.title: Actual Volatility on FOMC Days
item.description: FOMC days do not make much of a difference to tastytraders because we trade over a longer timeframe (45 DTE), and the only volatility that is observed due to the meeting is in the first hour.If any argument is to be made about the day-to-day interest rate volatility on FOMC days, it is actually lower than any marker day.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: FOMC days do not make much of a difference to tastytraders because we trade over a longer timeframe (45 DTE), and the only volatility that is observed due to the meeting is in the first hour.If any argument is to be made about the day-to-day inter...

item.title: Periods of High IV
item.description:
Implied volatility (IV) is a direct measure of option prices and provides option sellers with a measure of opportunity for profits. But high IV periods also tend to be the most dynamic times for the market. How can tastytraders do their best to profit from these atypical conditions without making unfounded assumptions? 

Today, Tom and Tony dive into the data surrounding the periods of highest IV from the past 17 years and see how long they lasted and how the market moved during those times.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

Implied volatility (IV) is a direct measure of option prices and provides option sellers with a measure of opportunity for profits. But high IV periods also tend to be the most dynamic times for the market. How can tastytraders do their best to profit from these atypical conditions without making unfounded assumptions? 

Today, Tom and Tony dive into the data surrounding the periods of highest IV from the past 17 years and see how long they lasted and how the market moved during those times.

item.title: Historical Volatility Accuracy
item.description: January was a month where realized volatility was larger than IV anticipated at the beginning of the month. This happens around 1 out of every 6 months on average.From February into March, IV has remained consistently high, and the realized volatility we experienced is actually on par with what IV was anticipating.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: January was a month where realized volatility was larger than IV anticipated at the beginning of the month. This happens around 1 out of every 6 months on average.From February into March, IV has remained consistently high, and the realized volati...

item.title: How Long Does a Week Last
item.description: Really eventful weeks can be large shocks to the market, but contrarian tastytraders often view them as opportunities. Today, Tom and Tony explore the data to see how long lasting the effects from these extreme moves can be.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Really eventful weeks can be large shocks to the market, but contrarian tastytraders often view them as opportunities. Today, Tom and Tony explore the data to see how long lasting the effects from these extreme moves can be.

item.title: BPR in High IV
item.description: Buying Power Reduction (BPR) is the capital required to place and hold an options trade.At any given time, we generally recommend allocating between 25% and 50% of BPR towards your options trades, with that amount varying depending on the underlying’s implied volatility (IV).With the VIX currently above 30, we decided to look into how BPR differs across various VIX levels and how that could impact your allocation now. Join Tom and Tony to find out!
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: What is with the VIX?
item.description: Tom and Tony explain what the VIX is, how it differs from a typical underlying, and what that means when it comes to trading VIX options.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom and Tony explain what the VIX is, how it differs from a typical underlying, and what that means when it comes to trading VIX options.
item.content:encoded: Tom and Tony explain what the VIX is, how it differs from a typical underlying, and what that means when it comes to trading VIX options.

item.title: Why Sell Premium?
item.description:
Option sellers have been profitable in the long term because they inherently take risk away from option buyers, and option sellers expect to be compensated for this risk transfer. The option seller’s historical long-run profitability does not mean that the market is inefficient. 

In exchange for the positive expected profitability given to option sellers, option buyers are met with peace of mind and limited risk for each of their trades.

In exchange for the positive expected profitability given to option sellers, option buyers are met with peace of mind and limited risk for each of their trades.

item.title: Judging Volatility
item.description: tastytraders are always on the lookout for high volatility opportunities to sell premium, but how can we tell if a given volatility is “high”? Today, Tom and Tony explain two normalized volatility metrics and use some data to help interpret them.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: tastytraders are always on the lookout for high volatility opportunities to sell premium, but how can we tell if a given volatility is “high”? Today, Tom and Tony explain two normalized volatility metrics and use some data to help interpret them.

item.title: How Long Does IVR Stay Bid
item.description: Since the start of the year, the major indices have seen their Implied Volatility Ranks (IVRs) over 50 quite frequently. 37% of the time for the S&P, 60% for the Nasdaq, and 47% of the time for the Russell.However, since volatility is mean reverting, it is unlikely that we see sustained periods of high IVR.When we see IVR start to increase, how long can we expect the indices to stay at or around that level before eventually decreasing?Join Tom and Tony to find out!
